community_water_challenges: Suri-Kachipo tribe still depending on streams and rivers water as no schools, no hospitals and no clean water
community_water_suggestions:
Improve water treatment 
Regulations and pricing policies on water Tanks 
Monitoring water quality 
Funding and sustainability in remote areas
additional_information:
Yes. In Mewun,Suri-Kachipo, access to safe drinking water is still very limited. Most people depend on rivers, streams, or hand-dug wells, which are often not protected from contamination. During the dry season, these water sources sometimes dry up, forcing families especially women and children to walk long distances in search of water.

The water available is usually not treated, and people drink it directly, which causes diseases such as diarrhea, typhoid, and cholera. There are no regular water testing services or treatment facilities in the area.
During the rainy season, flooding and open defecation around water points make the situation worse, as runoff contaminates the water sources. People also lack proper containers for water storage and purification methods like chlorine or filters.

Despite these challenges, the community is very willing to participate in improving water access if given training and tools. With support for borehole repairs, rainwater harvesting, and hygiene education, safe water access in Mewun could greatly improve.

additional_information: No

shortage_reason: High cost of water, Limited daily supply, Long distance to water source
school_water_challenges: Long queues, Water is expensive, Water is far from classrooms
community_water_challenges: In my community, one of the biggest challenges is the limited availability of clean and safe drinking water. Many households rely on water delivered by trucks or collected from boreholes, which are often far away and sometimes contaminated. During the dry season, water becomes scarce, and prices rise, making it difficult for low-income families to afford. In some areas, water storage tanks are not properly maintained, leading to health risks such as waterborne diseases.
community_water_suggestions: To improve access, the government and NGOs could invest in expanding the piped water network to reach more neighborhoods. Regular water quality testing and public awareness campaigns about water hygiene would also help prevent disease. Installing more community boreholes and providing affordable water purification systems, such as filters or chlorine tablets, could make a big difference. Additionally, better regulation of private water suppliers would ensure the water sold to the public meets safety standards.
additional_information: In some parts of Juba; particularly sherikat where I reside and some other parts that I have never been, people still depend on the Nile River for daily water use, which exposes them to unsafe water sources. Efforts to improve water infrastructure should also focus on educating the community about safe storage and treatment methods at home. With the right investment and community involvement, it is possible to make safe drinking water accessible and affordable for everyone in Juba.

community_water_suggestions: As a South Sudanese who is concerned about the well-being of our communities, I believe improving access to safe drinking water in Juba requires a collective and sustainable approach. First, we must invest in water purification system and protect existing water sources from contamination. The government in partnership with NGOs and international donars, should prioritize building and maintaining clean water infrastructure such as boreholes, protected well, and treatment facilities. Community education hygiene and safe water storage is also vital. Lastly, empowering local water committees to manage resources transparently will ensure long-term impact and ownership. Access to clean water is not a luxury its a right.
additional_information: No

Is expanding and upgrading water infrastructure,  specially in undeserved area. Increase investment in boreholes, water treatment plants, and rainwater harvesting system. Promote community education on water safety and hygiene. Strengthen government and NGOs partnership to ensure consistent funding and sustainable management of water resources.
